info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued July 07 at 2:33PM MDT until July 07 at 4:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING FOR THE HERMITS PEAK CALF CANYON BURN SCAR REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 PM MDT THIS AFTERNOON FOR NORTHWESTERN SAN MIGUEL COUNTY... At 233 PM MDT, While thunderstorms have moved away from the Hermits Peak-Calf Canyon Burn Scar, earlier rainfall will likely continue to produce runoff into downstream creeks and drainages. Between 0.25 and 0.75 inches of rain were estimated to have fallen earlier. Excessive runoff from the burn scar may impact the Tecolote Creek drainage area including Cabo Lucero Creek, Canon Mesteno, Ojitos Frios Creek, Gallina Creek and Tecolote Creek feeding into the Gallinas River. Any debris flows can consist of water, ash, soot, rock, mud, burned vegetation and other loose materials. HAZARD...Excessive runoff from earlier rainfall over the southeastern portion of the Hermits Peak-Calf Canyon Burn Scar. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Earlier rainfall may lead to flash flooding of southeastern portions of the Hermits Peak Calf-Canyon Burn Scar. Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Las Vegas, Montezuma, El Porvenir, Storrie Lake State Park, Romeroville, San Geronimo, Mineral Hill, Gallinas, San Pablo and Ojitos Frios. This includes the following highways... State Road 283 between Mile Markers 1 and 12...and near Mile Marker 14. State Road 65 between Mile Markers 2 and 14. State Road 518 near Mile Marker 7. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Runoff from earlier rainfall will cause elevated water levels within vulnerable drainages in and downstream of the Hermits Peak-Calf Canyon wildfire burn area. Do not camp along streams and rivers. Remain alert when hiking in steep, narrow canyons. Know where you are relative to low spots and drainages.
